por.por_cntn:
The ATE Workshop for Physics Faculty project principally provided professional development for two-year college and high school physics faculty.  Through an immersion in a three day intensive workshop or working conference, participants gained extensive experience and hands-on training in curricular and laboratory approaches/activities based on physics education research. As part of each workshop, the participants collaboratively developed and presented materials based on the curricular approach of the workshop. At each working conference, the participants wrote, tested, presented, and edited two laboratory activities which were tested and critiqued by the other participants.  The project provided all the workshop/working conference materials to the participants so they could implement the activities immediately in their physics programs after the workshop/working confernce they attended.

During the Project, fourteen workshops and nine working conferences were conducted at eight different two-year colleges in seven states. Of the four hundred and thirteen participants who attended these workshops/working conferences, two hundred and nineteen were two-year college physics faculty, one hundred and eighty-nine were high school physics faculty, and five were unniversity or middle school faculty.  Some participants attended more than one workshop/working conference.  The participants came from thirty-nine different states and represented two hundred and sixteen different institutions.Sixty-three percent of the participants were male and thirty-seven percent were females.  Nine different two-year college physics faculty members served as local site coordinators for at least one of the workshop/working conferences.  Nine different two-year college and university physics faculty served as workshop leaders.

Based on surveys of the participants, virtually all participants implemented some of the activities at their home institutions with many institutionalizing the curricular approach/activities in their physics program. From the survey responses, it was reported by the participants that over fifty thousand students per year, every year, experienced the curricular approach or activities from the workshops/working conferences.

The participants and leaders of the Project gave over one hundred presentations, posters or workshops at local, regional and national meetings based in part on the workshops/working conferences of the Project. Twenty-five of the laboratory activities developed at the working conferences are published on the Project's website (http://www.physicsworkshops.org/Labs_Activties/labs.html) and in a digital library for physics and astronomy.

The Project provided support and some of the leaders for the New Faculty Experience (NFE) for Two-Year College Physics Faculty project (http://aapt.org/Conferences/newfaculty/tyc2015.cfm), which provides professional development of new faculty in their first five years at a two-year college.  The Project, in association with the American Association of Physics Teaachers (http://aapt.org) and NFE, helped conduct the Two-Year College Physics Leadership Institutes, which provided training for experienced faculty to become national leaders for two-year college physics. The Project provided support for the Partnership for Integration of Computation into Undergraduate Physics (http://www.compadre.org/picup/) to conduct a six day immersion working conference to develop materials and to help establish a community of developers of computational materials for undergraduate physics.

Additional information about the Project can be found on its website: http://www.physicsworkshops.org.

 


Last Modified: 12/30/2016
Modified by: Thomas L O'kuma
